data.title: Better bit flag export
data.body:
So there's an option in GDScript to export bit flags, but it sets the values for you. To get the functionality I need, I have to make another dictionary.
```
enum MY_VAL {
    NONE                = 0x00,
    FLAG_1              = 0x11,
    FLAG_2              = 0x12,
    FLAG_3              = 0x14,
    FLAG_4              = 0x21,
    FLAG_5              = 0x22,
    FLAG_6              = 0x24,
    FLAG_7              = 0x41,
    FLAG_8              = 0x42,
    FLAG_9              = 0x44,
    MASK_1              = 0x01,
    MASK_2              = 0x02,
    MASK_3              = 0x03,
    MASK_4              = 0x10,
    MASK_5              = 0x20,
    MASK_6              = 0x30,
}

var MY_VAL_TO_HEX = {
    0 : MY_VAL.NONE,
    1 : MY_VAL.FLAG_1,
    2 : MY_VAL.FLAG_2,
    3 : MY_VAL.FLAG_3,
    4 : MY_VAL.FLAG_4,
    5 : MY_VAL.FLAG_5,
    6 : MY_VAL.FLAG_6,
    7 : MY_VAL.FLAG_7,
    8 : MY_VAL.FLAG_8,
    9 : MY_VAL.FLAG_9,
    10 : MY_VAL.MASK_1,
    11 : MY_VAL.MASK_2,
    12 : MY_VAL.MASK_3,
    13 : MY_VAL.MASK_4,
    14 : MY_VAL.MASK_5,
    15 : MY_VAL.MASK_6,
}

export (int,                  \
    "NONE",                 \
    "FLAG_1",               \
    "FLAG_2",               \
    "FLAG_3",               \
    "FLAG_4",               \
    "FLAG_5",               \
    "FLAG_6",               \
    "FLAG_7",               \
    "FLAG_8",               \
    "FLAG_9",               \
    "MASK_1",               \
    "MASK_2",               \
    "MASK_3",               \
    "MASK_4",               \
    "MASK_5",               \
    "MASK_6")               \
var my_val = 0

func do_stuff():
    var correct_my_val = MY_VAL_TO_HEX[my_val]
```

My suggestion is to make it so the export can do something like below. 
```
export (int, FLAGS,        \
    {"NONE" = 0x00},                 \
    {"FLAG_1" = 0x11},               \
```

data.title: Particles2D: Explosivness = 0 and Emit Timeout <= Lifetime - never emit
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10
Godot 2.1.3 - stable (current steam version)


**Issue description:**
When i set `Particles2D.Explosivness` to 0 (for some reason, any other value work, see workaround) and `Emit_Timeout` to <= `Lifetime`, emitter will not produce any particles when you call `set_emitting(true)`  (with exception of calling directly from `_ready()`)


**Steps to reproduce:**
- add Particles2D node
  - set `Lifetime` to x (lets say 3)
  - set `Explosiveness` to 0
  - set `Emit_Timeout` to anything <= x (let say 3 so `Emit_Timeout` = `Lifetime` or 2.9 so `Emit_Timeout` < `Lifetime`)
- add and enable (lets say, it works as expected from `_ready()`...) `_unhandled_key_input(key_event)`
- call `get_node("Particles2D").set_emitting(true)` from script function `_unhandled_key_input(key_event)` (added in prev step) - again, NOT from `_ready()` - that works.

Btw - when i was creating minimal example project, i noticed that if you set `Emit_timeout` to any float >= `Lifetime` (in my example, lets say 3.1) it looks like it start AFTER `Emit_Timeout` (3.1 sec) and i have strong feeling that it is related.

**Link to minimal example project:**
quick and dirty example: [buggy_emit.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1091268/buggy_emit.zip) - press space to emit.

**Workaround:**
Set Explosivness to 0.01 (difference is unnoticeable)

data.title: Editor MinGW build on Windows crashes upon opening a project
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:** Windows 10 - MinGW-w64 7.1.0 32-bit (posix, seh) - Godot Git https://github.com/godotengine/godot/commit/3c1fd26bb0c2e97b927343e5488aa6d646e2e27c


**Issue description:**
After starting the project manager (which works as expected), opening any project with Godot compiled using MinGW will cause the editor to crash. The crash does not occur immediately after clicking the "Edit" button â€“ it occurs a few seconds later.

Note that a 64-bit MSVC 2017-based build of the same commit does not have this issue.


**Steps to reproduce:**
Add a 32-bit MinGW-w64 installation to your `PATH`, then compile Godot using `scons platform=windows tools=yes target=release_debug bits=32`, then run the project manager and edit a project.

data.title: Segmentation fault at boot screen
data.body:
I'm working on linux and trying to get my build system setup.

when i build with:
scons -j 4 platform=x11 bits=64 builtin_openssl=yes
I get a working exe

if i use:
scons -j 4 platform=x11 tools=yes target=release_debug bits=64 builtin_openssl=yes
or
scons -j 4 platform=x11 tools=no target=release bits=64 builtin_openssl=yes

the generated exe loads the splash screen then crashes with a segmentation fault.
 gdb bt gives me:

#0  0x0000000001bbd520 in atomic_conditional_increment(unsigned int*) ()
#1  0x0000000001bd1f78 in Reference::init_ref() ()
#2  0x0000000001c187c8 in Image::load(String const&) ()
#3  0x00000000008ca56b in Main::start() ()
#4  0x00000000008b46a1 in main ()

I do have a custom boot splash image loaded.

data.title: Input Map: cannot map joypads with device numbers above zero
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Arch Linux, godot 3.0 f919be936b366f23388a8bcd99941d1fcd7cba73

**Issue description:**
Device numbers are reset to zero when saving joypad input mappings with device numbers above zero.  This is because:

1) InputEvents are serialized using the new generic Variant::Object serialization approach, which writes an object's member variables in a json-ish format (see variant_parser.cpp)
2) The device number is not written or read because it is set and retrieved using functions (InputEvent.get_device() and InputEvent.set_device(device))

I would fix this by making InputEvent.device a public variable, but if I did that I would probably also want to remove get_device and set_device because they are redundant, which would be a breaking change.

We should discuss the best way to fix this case, but we should probably also talk about how we will generically solve the "serializing/deserializing getters and setters" class of problems.

Semi-related question: Are there guidelines for when member variables should be hidden behind getters and setters in the godot codebase?  In the case of "device", get_device() just reads InputEvent.device and set_device(device) just writes to InputEvent.device.  Why does InputEvent.device need getters and setters, but public member variables like InputEvent.pressed don't?

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. map non-zero joypad in "Input Map" screen
2. save project 
3. reopen project
4. observe that the mapping is saved, but the device number is set to zero

data.title: Can't edit StreamTexture flags
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot master - 3c1fd26
Linux Mint 18.1 Cinnamon x64

**Issue description:**
The ability to set flags for a StreamTexture resource in the Inspector hasn't been implemented. Editing the flags manually via the .import files does work, so the functionality is there, but it isn't possible to do through the editor.

You can replicate this easily by adding a Sprite node and loading an image as a Texture, say, a .png file. In Godot 2.x an ImageTexture would be automatically created from the image, which has a Flags dropdown. In master it instead creates a StreamTexture, which has no Flags menu. Ideally it would have the same Flags dropdown as an ImageTexture resource.

Additionally, there doesn't seem to be a way to disable image filtering by default through the Project Settings menu anymore, but maybe that's for another issue.

data.title: [discussion] GraphNode lack of flexibility
data.body:
Hi everyone,

I am currently working on a new editor feature to create Finite State Machines. I started on designing the editor using GraphEdit and GraphNode classes. Those are great, but were initialy designed to handle "port-based" application.
In my case, I have no interest in using ports, but rather create transitions between nodes. Also I wanted to be able to modify the title bar to add the possibility to edit the node name (with a double click), which is not possible with the current implementation.

I wanted to suggest a new design for graph nodes that would split the graph nodes functionnalities into multiple parts:
- The GraphNode class becomes a generic container which only handles generic functions such as: resizability, offset on the graph...

Then two possibilities:
- We create a GraphNodePort class inheriting from GraphNode that implements all missing features.

or

- We create a PortContainer class that just extends the Container class with a set of displayed ports.
- We create a GraphNodePort class that includes this PortContainer class along with an HBoxContainer to create a top title / tool bar (or we built in from scratch into each editor depending on each specific needs).

I think the last solution is cleaner, as it truely split the functionalities and allow a very flexible design of graph nodes.

I could work on that but I would like to have more opinions about it.
What do you think ?

data.title: Camera2D enhancements (V2)
data.body:
![camera2d_enhancements](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25082678/27355809-4ea61c4e-55da-11e7-9677-359e0b1741fa.png)
I added various enhancements for Camera2D:

    Added an option to draw Camera2D's limits
    Added an option to draw Camera2D's drag margin
    Made drawing the Camera's screen bounds optional
    Put all of these option under a new group, "Editor helpers", in Camera2D
    Made Camera2D's editor lines less transparent if is set to current
    Added function calls to _update_scroll() in various places so the editor lines are updated when the values change
    Added variables and set/get functions for toggling the editor lines.

I can remove or change anything if needed. I'm not sure on changing the transparency on the editor lines, but I liked being able to see if a camera was current or not at a glance.

There is one issue I couldn't figure out how to fix. If you scale the Camera2D node by a negative value, the limit bounds editor lines start moving.

(Accidentally messed up git on previous pull request. Made a new pull request to fix the git issues.)

Closes #8175

data.title: orientation changes cause crash or other issues on iOS
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
iPhone 5S, iOS 10.3.1, Godot v2.1.3

**Issue description:**
There seem to be multiple problems with orientation changes on iOS

1. If your project supports multiple orientations, when an orientation change occurs on iOS, it seems like there is a 50% or greater chance Godot will crash (see https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/7945 for related issue). From what I've observed, **"501 error"** will be printed to the console many times while the orientation change is occurring. The crash seems to occur when the orientation change should finish.

2. Additionally, I have a `TextureFrame` with a screen shader in a project that I am resizing when the viewport size changes. On iOS, this causes nothing to render on that `CanvasLayer`. Rotating back to the original orientation does not fix it. I am also calling this resizing function once at startup from `_ready` but that does not cause an issue. FWIW I am using the following project settings and calling `set_size_override` on the viewport for custom sizing through my `Camera2D`:
- orientation = "sensor"
- stretch_aspect = "ignore"
- stretch_mode = "2d"

3. "reverse_portrait" orientation mode does not seem to be supported regardless of the project settings or supported orientations in the Xcode project's .plist

I've tested this on many of the demo projects as well and the first and third issue are still prevalent

Probably doesn't need to be said, but setting a single explicit orientation does not cause any issues

**Steps to reproduce:**
Enable multiple orientations in the project settings and Xcode project. Run on an iOS device and rotate to different orientations

data.title: fixed ptrcall cast for const Ref<T>
data.body:
Some methods require a const Ref<T> argument,
the ptrcall method wrappers cast `void *` to the
apropriate types. The problem is that there is no `Ref(const T *)`
constructor, but since Ref modifies the refcount of a Reference
anyway there's no point in a const version.

The problem is that with a `const T *` constructor call, the
argument gets converted to Variant first and loses all the
reference information, resulting in a null reference as the
argument to the constructor.

data.title: GDScript import plugins are not working properly
data.body:
Custom import plugins are misbehaving most of the time.

- Custom resources does not appear on the FileSystem dock at first. They appear if you reimport something then unfocus/refocus the editor, and even then only the current folder shows. Deleting the `.import` folder also seems to work but only the first time, so it does not help when the editor is reopened.
- They also don't reappear if you deactivate and reactivate the plugin.
- The import presets does not appear on the list.
- Adding a custom importer for an existing resource doesn't seem to make a difference. The "Import As" dropdown doesn't seem to do anything.
- The editor crashes on exit if the plugin is active.

data.title: Make the Windows icon file smaller
data.body:
This results in slightly more compact Godot Windows binaries. The same icon sizes are available in the file (from 16Â² to 256Â²).

Before-after comparison on hiDPI and with very large icons:

![godot_windows_icon_comparison](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/180032/27333576-a43358e8-55c6-11e7-9eca-87d2272d1966.png)

A 64-bit editor binary in `release_debug` mode is now 253 KB smaller (29,622 KB instead of 29,875 KB).

data.title: Vector2 AND when performing comparisons
data.body:
```
print(Vector2(0, 0) > Vector2(0, 1)); # False
print(Vector2(1, 1) > Vector2(0, 1)); # True
print(Vector2(1, 0) > Vector2(0, 100)); # True
print(Vector2(0, 5) > Vector2(1, 0)); # False
```
It seems like it's testing `v1.x > v2.x` specifically instead of doing `v1.x > v2.x && v1.y > v2.y`.

It would make comparison of a point in an area much easier (such as `point >= start && point <= start +size`).

Only negative is that `vec1 < vec2` is not the same as `!(vec1 > vec2)`, but I don't think that's so much of an issue compared to the current formula.

data.title: "Small Deploy with Network" with .local domain fails in Godot 2.1.3 & iOS (regression)
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
iOS 10.1.3 - Godot 2.1.3

**Issue description:**
Using the "Small Deploy with Network" requires the argument "-rfs <IP>". 
In earlier versions, setting the argument "-rfs MacBook.local" (the Mac's name is "MacBook") worked, since it resolves for the Mac's IP which may change every time you connect to a network. In Godot 2.1.3 it no longer works, and crashes, unless you set the IP, which you have to update every now and then manually


**Steps to reproduce:**
1.- Run a Godot Project and enable Small Deploy With Network.
2.- Downloading the export templates, uncompressing the iOS template and installing the Xcode project with Arguments Passed On Launch set to "-rfs <Mac'sName.local>" will crash on launch
3.- Replacing the executable (godot_debug.iphone) with an earlier version runs perfectly well (I'm not sure if the version I used for replacing is 2.1.1 or 2.1.2, it has a modified date of November 16, 2016)

data.title: Fixed freelook conflict with text inputs
data.body:
Selecting a text input such as shader editor or AnimationPlayer's input fields wasn't playing well with freelook, since focus isn't given to viewport on left click.

However, one thing I was unable to solve is how to capture keyboard input while freelook is active... (it uses `_process`, and viewport input doesn't uses `_forward_spatial_input` either) at the moment they are still ending up in `_unhandled_input` callbacks (found this on the way #9280)

data.title: It's possible to use AnimationPlayer shortcuts without animation selected, and crash Godot
data.body:
Latest Godot, Windows 10 64 bits

Repro steps:
1) Create a new project
2) Open the AnimationPlayer tab
3) Press "S" (shortcut for "stop"), observe crash

I ran into this issue while fixing a freelook bug, and pressing S was catched by the AnimationPlayer's `_unhandled_input` (because freelook uses `_process()`, not `_gui_input`, so it could not consume the event).

By the way... how would I consume key events? Freelook works per viewports, because SpatialEditorPlugin doesn't uses `forward_spatial_gui_input`...

data.title: Fixed a string class bug
data.body: that_str is supposed to identify with the passed parameter, otherwise the comparison makes no sense
